Take a look at the link I gave you.

There is a app called startup applications, it needs to be loaded to see what runs at startup, you can turn off stuff you don't use like say bluetooth if your'e not using it etc, be careful here, the benefits are small but they are there.  sudo sed -i 's/NoDisplay=true/NoDisplay=false/g' /etc/xdg/autostart/*.desktop
sudo sed -i 's/NoDisplay=true/NoDisplay=false/g' /etc/xdg/autostart/*.desktop
I figured you had a gig, I would run lxde, or lubuntu if it were me.
here is what it looks like, you can install it and run it or what you have now with a gear dropdown at the login line.
They are pretty much the same I think lubuntu just has a few more apps.
lxde and lubuntu just use some of the same basic apps, but different versions, for example leafpad as a text app rather then gedit.
You would still have the software center it probably is in lxde, if installed in ubuntu, but you have it already it will not be removed.

Some of us will have several desktops, I do as I like the gnome-shell more then unity, so I just install the shell on a regular ubuntu install that has unity. There is a website as well that has the complete package lists for the 4 main desktops used with ubuntu, so if you wanted you can remove a extra desktop if you wanted.
If you are installing like lxde or lubuntu in ubuntu it is just another desktop environment
At the login window you will see a gear next to the login line that is a drop down for choosing the desktop you want to run.
